case_vignette: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of right hip pain that started that afternoon. His mother reports that he has also been limping since the pain developed. He says that the pain worsens when he moves or walks. He participated in a dance recital yesterday, but his mother believes that he was not injured at the time. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of nasal congestion and mild cough 10 days ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis and his grandmother has osteoporosis. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. His right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated. Examination shows no tenderness, warmth, or erythema. He is able to bear weight. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.3 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 8,500/mm3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Ultrasound of the right hip shows increased fluid within the joint. X-ray of the hips shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having pain in my right hip since this afternoon, and it's making me limp.
How old are you?
I am 6 years old.
Is the pain in your hip constant, or does it come and go?
The pain gets worse when I move or walk.
Have you had any recent injuries, falls, or infections?
I had a mild cough and nasal congestion 10 days ago, but I don't think I was injured during my dance recital yesterday.
Have you experienced any fever or warmth in the affected hip?
My temperature is a little high at 99.6°F, but there's no warmth on my hip.
Have you noticed any redness or swelling around your hip?
No, there's no redness or swelling.
Have you ever had hip pain like this before, or is this the first time?
This is the first time I've had this hip pain.
Do you have any difficulty moving your leg or does the hip feel stiff?
I can move my leg, but the pain gets worse when I do.
Does the pain in your hip get better with rest?
I haven't mentioned if the pain gets better with rest, just that it worsens when I move or walk.
I apologize for the oversight. When you rest, does the pain decrease or does it stay the same?
I haven't said anything about the pain when I rest.
Have you taken any medication for the pain?
I haven't mentioned taking any medication for the pain.
Have any of your family members had similar symptoms or been diagnosed with joint conditions?
My mother has rheumatoid arthritis.
Final Diagnosis: Transient synovitis (irritable hip)
